poem:
"Ballads of Bygone Beats"

Pitchfork, the standard of sound, into glossy GQ dressed,
A travesty to tunes, anguish in our shared breast.
Circled in a writer's den, a Norse night revealed.
Zach's words kindled kinship, music's mystery unsealed.
Yet now, with aching heart, we glimpse the fading crest,
Once vibrant voices silenced, shackled at corporate behest.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Pitchfork’s absorption into GQ is a travesty for music media – and musicians | Laura Snapes In late summer 2011, I was in Norway covering a music festival for NME. One night at a party in another writer’s hotel room, I got talking to an American guy called Zach Kelly. Zach, it turned out, wrote for Pitchfork. As a 22-year-old music journalism freak, I could only imagine this was how it must feel to meet". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
